                       EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

                                

   South Carolina Electric and Gas Company - Wateree Station

                    Eastover, South Carolina

                        Richland County





OVERVIEW



The SCE&G Wateree Station is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees,

contractors, the surrounding community, and the environment.  To meet this commitment, we have

established systems to ensure safe operation of plant processes, which includes the safe and proper

handling of hazardous substances at the plant.  One component of these systems is a Risk

Management Program (RMP), which manages the risks involved with using hazardous substances. 

Wateree Station's RMP complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's

(EPA's) regulation 40 CFR  68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements:  Risk Management

Programs.  This regulation is also referred to as "the RMP rule".  One of the requirements of the

RMP rule is to submit an executive summary in the Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) describing

the RMP at the Wateree Station.  This document is intended to satisfy the executive summary

requirement of the RMP rule and to provide a description of the RMP.  



The Wateree Station is the largest fossil plant in SCE&G system.  The plant generates 700

megawatts of electricity by burning pulverized coal in two identical generation units.  Wateree

Station's Unit 1 began commercial operation in 1970, and Unit 2 began operation in 1971.  To

comply with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, SCE&G must reduce 85% of the total Nitrogen

Oxides (NOx) emitted system-wide by May, 2004.  After exhaustive studies, SCE&G determined

that Wateree Station would install a Selective Catalytic Reduction Reactor (SCR) for each of

Wateree Station's generating units.  Inside each SCR, anhydrous ammon

ia is sprayed into the exit

gas as it leaves the boiler and then the gas is processed through a series of ceramic plates (referred

to as catalyst), converting the NOx into nitrogen (an inert gas) and water vapor.  Design engineering

indicated the need to install two 60,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia storage tanks to support

operation of the SCRs.  Operation of the SCRs will be year round.



The Wateree Station Risk Management Program consists of three elements:



  1. A hazard assessment to identify (a) the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental

  releases and (b) accidents that have occurred during the last 5 years associated with the

  substances regulated by the RMP rule (see Sections 3 and 5 of this executive summary);

  

  2. A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate processes containing significant

  quantities of substances regulated by the RMP rule (see Section 4 of this executive summary);

  and


OVERVIEW (CON'T.)

  

  3. An emergency response program to provide guidance to the plant for responding to accidental

  releases of regulated substances from processes covered by the RMP rule (see Section 6 of this

  executive summary).



Although the RMPlan helps ensure that Wateree Station's RMP covered system is maintained and

operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the plant's overall safety program.  In fact,

a comprehensive safety program exists that establishes many levels of safeguards against accidents.





CONSIDERATIONS



Limiting the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule.



SCE&G did perform a thorough evaluation before selecting a pollution control technology that uses

a hazardous substance regulated by the RMP rule ("regulated substance").  The potential for the

hazardous substance to affect individuals and the environment has been considered, and SCE&G has

taken the appropriate steps to address the hazards.



Preventing releases of the regulated substances used.



When a

regulated substance is used, the equipment that contains it is carefully designed, built, and

operated to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  All applicable federal, state, corporate,

and industry standards are strictly adhered to in the design, construction, and operation of the

equipment.



Limiting damage from a release, if such a release occurs.



SCE&G Wateree Station's main objective is to prevent the accidental release of anhydrous ammonia

from occurring.  In the unlikely event of a release, employees are trained to recognize accidental

releases, quickly assess the severity of a release, and respond to mitigate and stop the release. 

Coordination with the county's Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) is crucial to protect

the health and safety of the surrounding community.  Emergency planning efforts have been

performed with Richland County Emergency Services, and SCE&G will continue to work closely

with them.  In addition, the LEPCs for the adjacent communities (Sumter County and Calhoun

County) have been informed.  In short, actions have been taken to ensure appropriate plans are in

place to minimize the impact of a release on our employees and the community.




The SCE&G safety program consists of a number of elements, many of which are beyond what is

required by the RMP rule.  This RMPlan executive summary is written to describe only those parts

of the safety program required by the RMP rule for Wateree Station.





ELEMENTS



  1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



SCE&G is committed to the safety of its employees and contractors, the public, and to the protection

of the environment.  All appropriate steps have been taken to prevent the accidental release of

anhydrous ammonia.  These steps include (a) training programs for personnel, (b) programs to help

ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our process, and (c) programs

to evaluate the hazards of o

ur processes.



In the event of an accidental release, SCE&G will be prepared to respond in a manner that will be

safe for our employees and will minimize any injury to the public and the environment.  The plant

has a trained and equipped Emergency Response Team that is highly qualified to mitigate releases

from the RMP covered system.  The planning efforts performed in conjunction with Richland

County Emergency Services / Columbia-Richland Fire Service will help ensure proper coordination

of emergency response personnel.





2.   REGULATED SUBSTANCE USED AT SCE&G WATEREE STATION



The Wateree Station has one substance (anhydrous ammonia) in sufficient quantity to be regulated

by the RMP rule.  The anhydrous ammonia used at the plant is covered as a toxic material by the

RMP rule.  As stated previously, anhydrous ammonia will be used as a reactant to reduce the

emission of NOx from the plant.





3.   OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



    No Description per changes in executive summary requirements.





4.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC

   PREVENTION STEPS



SCE&G has developed a comprehensive prevention program that complies with the Occupational

Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  For

Wateree Station, the prevention program requirements of EPA's RMP rule are also satisfied by this

PSM program.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of our prevention program that

address the RMP rule requirements.

   
   4.1  Prevention Program



The accident prevention program for anhydrous ammonia consists of the following 12 elements:





     4.1.1  Process Safety Information



A number of technical documents are maintained and are readily available at the plant, including an

emergency preparedness plan (called the Integrated Contingency Plan, or "ICP"), to help ensure that

plant and local emergency responders are aware of the hazards.  These documents address (

a)

physical properties of anhydrous ammonia, (b) operating parameters for the equipment, and (c)

design basis and configuration for the equipment.  This process safety information is available to our

employees and contractors, as well.



     4.1.2  Process Hazard Analysis



Process Hazard Analysis of the anhydrous ammonia process was performed and will be periodically

updated to identify process hazards, as well as to establish recommendations that will improve the

safe operation of the RMP covered process.  A multidisciplinary team was assembled to analyze the

hazards of the anhydrous ammonia storage and handling process.  This team includes personnel with

engineering / process operating experience and a leader with experience in performing Process

Hazard Analyses.  The team systematically addressed the hazards associated with operation of the

equipment in the anhydrous ammonia system.  The team then prepared a written report describing

the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations.  Responsibility for resolving the

recommendations was assigned to plant personnel, and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the

safety of the system were implemented.  This analysis is revised at least every 5 years to ensure it

is current.



     4.1.3  Operating Procedures 



Wateree Station's engineers, operators, and the Plant Manager worked together to develop and

maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to ammonia system operations should be

safely performed.  The operating procedures are used to train employees and serve as reference

guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.  Operating

procedures include:



  ?  Steps for safely conducting activities

  ?  Applicable safety information, such as safety operating limits and consequence of deviations

  ?  Safety and health considerations, such as chemical hazards, personal protective equipment

  requirements, and actions to t

ake if exposure to a hazardous substance occurs.

   
   4.1.4    Training



Employees are trained to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks.  The training program

includes both initial and refresher training that covers (a) a general overview of the system, (b) the

properties and hazards of anhydrous ammonia, and (c) a detailed review of the operating procedures

and safe work practices.  Classroom training and demonstrations are used to help impart knowledge

to the employees.  Tests and demonstrations are used to verify that an employee understands the

training material before the employee can work on the anhydrous ammonia system.



     4.1.5  Mechanical Integrity



The anhydrous ammonia handling equipment is maintained to help prevent equipment failures that

could endanger employees and contractors, the public, or the environment. The mechanical integrity

(preventive maintenance) program includes (a) an inspection and testing program to help identify

equipment deterioration and damage well before the equipment can fail and (b) a quality assurance

function to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the strict design standards required

for service in our process.



     4.1.6  Management of Change



The Management of Change procedure is a written procedure that requires the review and approval

of all proposed changes to the anhydrous ammonia system.  This includes chemicals, equipment,

technology, and procedures to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. 

All changes other than replacement-in-kind (e.g., replacing a valve with an identical valve) must be

approved through the Management of Change procedure.  This helps to ensure that inadvertent

consequences of changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected

process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the

changes.



4.1.7  Pre-startup Safety Review



Safety

reviews of new or modified processes are performed before placing them into service to help

ensure their safe operation.  This review confirms that:



  ?  construction activities and equipment are in accordance with design specifications;

  ?  adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place;

  ?  employee training has been completed; and

  ?  for a covered process ("regulated process"), a Process Hazard Analysis has been performed if

  the process is new, or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing

  process has been modified.

   
   4.1.8    Compliance Audit



One of the cornerstones of an effective prevention program is a regular, thorough assessment.  A

program is in place to perform compliance audits of our RMP-covered processes every 3 years to

be certain the prevention program is effectively addressing the safety issues of the process.  These

audits are performed by an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the PSM and RMP

regulations and in our process designs, and this team evaluates whether the prevention program

satisfies the requirements of these two regulations and whether it is sufficient to help ensure safe

operation of the ammonia system.  The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are

resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.



     4.1.9  Incident Investigation



A program is in place to investigate any incidents or near misses that could reasonably result in

serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented

in the future.  The requirements to identify and report any incident requiring investigation are

communicated to employees.  In the event of an incident, an investigation team would be assembled,

and the investigation would be initiated as soon as possible, but always within 48 hours of the

incident.  The results of the investigation are document

ed, recommendations are resolved, and

appropriate process improvements are implemented.



     4.1.10 Employee Participation



A written employee participation program exists for our RMP covered process to help ensure that

the safety concerns of our employees are addressed.  We encourage active participation of personnel

in the prevention program activities of all processes at the plant.  Employees are consulted and

informed about all aspects of our accidental release prevention program.



     4.1.11 Hot Work Permits



A Hot Work Permit Program exists, which is intended to control spark or flame-producing activities

that could result in fires or explosions at Wateree Station.  This program conforms to OSHA

requirements.  Training on hot work activities and on the requirements of the hot work permit

program is included in our new employee orientation.

   
   4.1.12   Contractors



A program is in place to help ensure that contractor activities related to the RMP covered ammonia

system are performed in a safe manner.  Contractor supervisors are informed of the hazards of the

processes on which they and their employees will work, our safe work practices, and our emergency

response procedures.  Contractors are required to ensure that training has been performed for each

of their employees before he/she performs work at the plant.  Routine verification that this training

has been provided is performed.





4.2   Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



In addition to the required prevention program elements, safety features specific to the anhydrous

ammonia process have been implemented.



The anhydrous ammonia is delivered in tank trucks that must be approved by the Department of

Transportation.  The plant's anhydrous ammonia storage tanks and equipment are designed and

maintained to standards established by the federal government and by industry.  Manual shutoff

valves, excess flow devices in the storage tank, and ammonia detectors with alarms are

provided as

process controls to help prevent or mitigate releases of anhydrous ammonia from the system.





5.   FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no recordable releases of anhydrous ammonia within the last five years.  The

anhydrous ammonia system has been designed to codes and standards that were established to

minimize the possibility of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia from the system that could

result in exposure to employees, contractors, the public, or the environment.






6.   EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS



Wateree Station's Emergency Response Team personnel will respond to an accidental release of

ammonia.  The Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) has been developed to help facilitate the

evacuation of employees and to ensure the safety of SCE&G and local emergency responders who

could be called on to respond to an accidental releases.  The ICP addresses:



  ?  informing local emergency responders about accidental releases that could reasonably result in

  offsite consequences;

  ?  providing emergency medical assistance;

  ?  obtaining outside assistance to control and contain accidental releases of hazardous substances;

  and

  ?  plan review and upkeep.



Employees are trained to recognize and report known, or even perceived, emergency situations. 

Employees and contractors are trained in evacuation procedures.  The county LEPC (Richland

County Emergency Services) is responsible for notifying the public of the emergency situation and

coordinating with other public safety agencies and LEPCs, if necessary.



The ICP complies with other federal contingency plan regulations [i.e., OSHA regulation 29 CFR

1910.38(a) and 1910.120(q)], and a copy of the plan has been provided to the Richland County

LEPC.  In addition, a hazardous material inventory has been provided to the LEPC and local fire

department, as required by the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act.  Wateree

Station personnel will maintain a

regular dialogue with local emergency planners.





7.   PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



SCE&G is committed to continuous improvement of the "safety process" using recommendations

developed through the prevention program and a program soliciting safety suggestions from our

employees.  Standard operating and safety procedures for the RMP covered process are reviewed

periodically to ensure that they are correct, and training is provided to employees on a wide variety

of safety and operating topics.
